A simple electronic circuit and a printable housing to make an electrical polarity tester  
Use it to check your electronic circuits.  It will tell you which wire is live, which is ground, or even if it's AC.  
Designed to work on circuits from around 3-15V.

OVERVIEW This is a simple polarity tester circuit that I use with my electronics projects. It's good for a quick sanity check, to see whether two connections have a voltage across them. The circuit tells me which of the two has the highest voltage, or if the voltage is AC. The LED will shine:
  • GREEN if the probe to your RIGHT is positive, or
  • RED if the probe to the LEFT is positive.
  • YELLOW if the circuit is AC.
    • You hold the device with the two "probes" pointing away from you, and touch it to your circuit. Of course you may need to use some croc/alligator clips.

CONSTRUCTION Build the circuit by taking a bicolor LED and soldering a 1500R resistor to its cathode (that's the SHORTER of the two leads). I do that by making a loop in the lead as close to the body of the LED as possible, then clipping off the remainder of the lead. Then slide the resistor into the loop to hold it in place while I solder. The anode lead of the LED now needs to be bent out sideways, and wrapped around a bolts, which act as one probe for the tester. Do the same with the lead from the resistor to make the second probe (see image). The nut and bolt came from Home Depot: "4-40 x 1/4 x 3/32" according to the packaging. I use two nuts per bolt, one on each side of the lead.

HOUSING Place the electronics inside the 3D printed housed. When mounting the electronics ensure you have RESISTOR TO THE RIGHT (see image). Another nut on each bolt is used to hold the electronics in place in the housing. This means you will need six nuts and two bolts. As the picture shows, the probe with the resistor is on the right. IF YOU GET THIS WRONG, THE LED POLARITY INDICATION WILL BE SWITCHED. The cap can now be put on the housing. The two halves should latch together, but if you like, you can add glue to hold the housing closed.
See my YouTube video for additional assembly instructions: http://youtu.be/xc9GlTj9xAQ

WARNING TESTED WITH VOLTAGES FROM 3 VOLTS TO 15 VOLTS PLEASE WATCH YOUR MAX OPERATING VOLTAGE Most of your home hobby electronics will be in the 3 to 9 volt range, so the circuit is designed to tolerate those voltages. The resistor in series with the LED is 1500R, which is about 10times larger than you would normally use for current limit on an LED. This means the circuit shouldn't explode in normal operating voltages, but the LED will be a little dimmer than you might normally expect.

description.text: 1 of 3 of the Fresh Prints Series.
1 of 3 from the Fresh Prints series.

Based upon http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13677 I had the idea to include a few more fonts in my fonts -> OpenScad website. I have now added all the Google webfonts, http://www.google.com/webfonts, just 470 fonts are available at http://sign-generator.b9c.org/ I have not tested all 470 fonts. A few give me - "ERROR: Illegal polygonal object - make sure all polygons are defined with the same winding order. Skipping affected object." One or two of the thick fonts, come are only the edge extruded (hollow letters). However most work. Sign-generator-openscad So I am waiting for a Printrbot. I wanted something simple to print out as my first print. I really liked the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14728 Printrbot ID with number on thingiverse.com. I downloaded the files and played with it, but I wanted to customise it a little more. Have looked around at https://www.google.com/search?q=openscad+3d+text+tutorial openscad 3d text tutorials, I wanted something that was really simple to use, so here it is:- http://sign-generator.b9c.org/ Go to New Sign enter some text, some dimensions, look at the preview - download the files. Viola. How it works: Django applcaiton. The text is made in to a SVG graphics file. Using inkscape, the SVG is converted to a eps files - and a PNG used for previewing. The eps is then converted to dxf using pstoedit. The a text files is generated for OpendSCAD which extrudes the dxf file. Further details can be gained from the sources files - http://code.google.com/p/sign-generator-openscad/ The server is host a very, very cheap VPS. So sometime the production of file may take up to 1 min. Thanks to OpenSCAD
Thanks to MCAD https://github.com/elmom/MCAD Brook, is it February yet ? Regards,
Brendan M. Sleight
@bmsleight
Go to http://sign-generator.b9c.org/ enter some text, dimensions. Look at the preview and then download the OpenSCAD and DXF file. Simple.

This is a prototype of ongoing Braille educational toys development.
It's simply a cube with letters. Design allows to print six identical cube sides and pins for it. Next, pins are used to form Braille font letter, after that cube can be assembled and glued. Or, without glue it can be used as puzzle.

WARNING!
Use SIDE_01_07_16_release.stl if you experience issues with printing quality - this one has 0.25mm error included.
If your printer doesn't have such problems - use SIDE_07_07_16_release.stl instead

CHANGELOG:
1.07.2016 Reviewed design in order to minimize time and plastic usage.
7.07.2016 Added file suitable for hi-quality printing.

More info on Braille educational materials on our team website: http://braille-device.com/en/

You may write me if you want to get additional support or want to get source models.

Assembly manual

To make full cube first print six sides and six set of pins. You can print less pin sets, but make sure you'll have enough to make characters. Below I add English Braille alphabet, that you can use as reference. Side has specific mark - filled corners, so the blind person know, how to read it properly.

Note
Ukrainian Braille readers usually expect this mark to be below letter. Ensure that you assemble cubes in convenient way for blind persons in your region.

*Source: http://fontmeme.com/images/Braille-Alphabet-550x466.png* Step 1

When printing is finished, carefully cut pins. I recommend using side cutters, but knife is fine too. You will get 6 round dots and 6 flat caps.

Each pin has square base, thin connections should be removed Left - flat cap, right - round dot. Pins after cutting Step 2

Now form a letter by inserting pins into side. It is supposed to use reasonable amount of violence while putting them, so glue is optional. Holes in the side are pretty tight, you may need to grind pins. Make 6 sides for each cube you want to make.

Here's the front side of letter Reverse side. Six sides with pins. Letters, from top left: E, G, B, D, A, W. Step 3

Now, time to assemble sides to get cube. Since all sides are identical, it's hard to assemble cube in wrong way. Connections between sides are also tight, so you may grind these too. Usually, no glue required.

Here's the way you assemble sides. And final cube. Notice leftover pins - one set allows to make any letter, so there always be some leftovers. It's ready! You're awesome!

Typically it's enough to make 16 cubes for making nearly every word in Ukrainian language. Since English has shorter average word length, I assume 10 cubes will be enough.

Note
Depending on language cubes will have different letters on them. But, I can't advise you some ready-made solution on how to choose letters. Simplest way - go to nearest toy shop and buy some letter cubes for sighted, to recreate those for the blind.

I've been looking for ways to anchor boards like Arduinos or Raspberry Pis onto enclosures. Until now, I've been making various custom clip designs. Like my:

  • Generic Clip
  • Arduino Clip
  • Raspberry Pi Clip

However each board needs a clip tailored to the specific positions of the mounting holes. Instead I thought I'd just have clips which fit into the mounting holes, and which you can glue directly on some baseboard.

This solution is independent of the mounting hole positions. It doesn't matter if you have a Raspberry Pi Model Zero, 1 or 2, A or B. An Arduino uno or Mega. Just put the pegs in the mounting holes and glue them onto the board. It's as simple as that.

OpenSCAD file provided, allowing you to customize height and diameters.

remixed_from.title: Auto leveling probe holder for Prusa I3 X One Extruder

title: Auto leveling probe holder for Prusa I3 for 8mm sensor

description.text:
The auto-leveling probe holder for Geeetech Prusa I3 X with a single extruder. This is a remix, as I used the 8mm sensor which has an 18mm diameter as opposed to the 12mm diameter sensor.

Connects to the extruder bracket with a couple M3 bolts and square nuts.

The Extruder used is this one:

  • LJ18A3-8-Z/BX 8mm Approach Sensor Inductive Proximity NPN NO Switch DC 6-36V

In converting my printer to use the auto-leveling probe I found the following 2 links very useful:

  • http://www.instructables.com/id/Enable-Auto-Leveling-for-your-3D-Printer-Marlin-Fi/?ALLSTEPS
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EcGFLwj0pnA

To summarize how I connected my probe to the printer:

  • pulled 12V from the connector that runs from the power supply to the board.
  • used a 15k and 10k ohm resister as per the instruction links above
  • disconnected the one lead from the z-stop sensor and connected that to the probe
  • modified my config.h file as per the instructional video

After installing and testing the probe I've found my prints to be 100 times better than before! Everything is so much more smooth and crisp, it's unbelievable! Definitely recommend this accessory!

title: Cheerson CX-20 Quanum Nova Gimbal Mount Plate

description.text:
This is a mounting plate for installing a cheap 2-axis gimbal to a Cheerson CX-20/Quanum Nova quadcopter. This allows the gimbal to be moved forward to avoid blocking access to the auxiliary connections/usb port on the bottom of the quadcopter.

Printed in PLA, 25% infill, with supports.

Thanks to iskor12 for the original design. I modified it from his original design to allow the gimbal to be bolted on instead of snapping into place.

comments.text: Thanks, though I can't take full credit for the design.  It does affect how the quad flies a bit, but with a little tuning  and calibration it works fine.  As far as durability goes, Ive had one big crash since using it, and even though it bent the aluminum mounting plate on the gimbal, the printed plate fared just fine.

comments.text: This looks like a great solution for mounting a gimbal to a CX20, I'm thinking of having one made.  Did you experience any issues with stability/manoeuvrability of the drone with the gimbal and camera mounted so far forwards?

author: Cornflake

description.text:
Made for our trip to Disneyland for New Years Eve.
We go every year and I think I will make one for every year now too!
All rights reserved by Disney, although I free-handed this design on Google Sketch Up from scratch with out physical reference to their "Mouse Head"
(Disney please contact me directly if you want this removed)
Print, wear, be happy!

I needed a wall mount for my Arduino Uno that had easy removal options. This design uses zip ties to secure the Arduino and the whole thing slides up and out of the mounts for quick swiping.

Print up a left and right mount and one of the Uno Holders. Screw in the mounts, attach the uno to the holder with zip ties. (it will be elevated above the bottom of the holder)

I created this design in the IMA* Fabrication Lab of NYU Shanghai, to organize the sewing threads we have in the Soft Lab, but I wanted it to be inexpensive. In order to do that, I am using re purposed material that we got from equipment packages.

*IMA: Interactive Media Arts Program

Photos by Kevin Bin Ni

I designed this using Rhino and then I cut the pieces in an Epilog laser cutter.
The cardboard I used it is around 5~6mm thick. The joints are thigh so I didn't have to use glue between them.

The settings for the laser cutter were:
Speed: 80
Power: 50
Frequency: 500

But I had to do it twice because it didn't cut the first time.

I found with the original that my bag would come loose and even the hook would come loose from the seat so I created this one. Since it's thin it's easy to twist a little to open up the hook to install yet it won't come loose on it's own.  
I use 2, one on each headrest post and this holds the bag in a more open position. I have been making these for family members and they love them.

Watch this video for more information: https://youtu.be/yYGd5JoLars

For this model we take on Minecraft per the request of a viewer of my channel! I decided to go for a nice variety of characters, objects and animals in the game. So I chose Steve, the pig, and a TNT block.

These are pretty much purely square objects and don't have a lot of detail. Most of the detail in the game comes from the textures applied to the blocks. So I put a few lines around the blocks to mark out areas of different color to allow for easier painting and just providing some detail to the plain print.

If you like this time of thing, let me know and I'll make more like this. I'll even try to make them move if that's requested. :)

Post Processing:
Step 1: Sand/File any rough spots.
Step 2: Apply plastic primer. Give it a few coats, letting it dry completely in between.
Step 3: Apply the paint. We used a combination of a sponge dabber and a paintbrush to apply water based acrylic paints.

Print Settings:
Layer Height: 0.3mm
Infill: 20%
Supports: No
Raft: No

Notes:

Print using Simplify3D sequential printing model with all model origins aligned. Each model is printed using a different process and tool/filament changes to enable multi-coloured printing with a single nozzle.

Be sure to disable the print obstruction detection if printing on ZYXX+:
--> Go to “Utilities” on the ZYYX-> Scroll to “Total trig. Time(s)”-> Set Value to “0″.
The main model is designed and then colours are added as a seperate layer to 0.4mm depth.

remixed_from.author: Amadon
remixed_from.title: Amadon's Cyclops and Chimera Direct Drive Version 3

description.text:
This is a modified version of Amadon's Chimera direct drive extruder, with the following alterations:

  • I removed the right motor and idler and created a path for a bowden tube. The resulting half bowden, half direct drive system has several advantages over the original design:
    • it reduces the weight on the X carriage, and its width
    • it still allows the easy use of flexible filaments
    • it simplifies assembly, particularly removing the necessity of replacing the screws on the motors by 3mm threaded rods
  • I added a support for an induction probe
  • I added a support for a rear blow fan (http://e3d-online.com/Electrical/Fans/50x50x15mm-12v-DC-Side-Blow-Fan)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm layers

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Use .2mm layers, except the fan support (use .1 mm)

please follow the instructions for the amadon extruder with the exception that there is no need to replace the screws of the motors by threaded rods. Instead, use 60mm m3 screws to fix the probe to the extruder&motor

Modified the original extruder with 123d design and mesh mixer.
The probe and fan supports were designed with the same software

comments.text: Is this compatible with dual e3d titan extruders, nema 17 motors, and the prusa i3, or any of the knock off i3's? Also, what type of mounting hardware does this require, screws, locknuts, washers, etc? Also, would it be difficult for me to add a fan pointed at the bed?
comments.author: mikelee69

comments.text:
This is a "half" direct drive extruder; using a titan would be redundant (unless you want to use it to drive the bowden part of the system).
I use NEMA 17, with some M3 screws and washers to drive it.
For fan, I use this one
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1536352
Fixes directly on the heatsink and works pretty well, if you take care to check that it does not drag on the piece you are printing

The tantillus a2 printer has a limited build volume (10cm10cm10cm) , so I plan to build this one - a3 , this one have the build volume of 16cm16cm16cm, this will cover most use cases for 3d printing hobbyist.

I use corner connectors instead of top and bottom panels in tantillus a2 , this is because the top panel make maintenance difficult (tighten cable, replace hotend, etc). for all other components , download from tantillus a2 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:480860), they can be reused in a3 version, (x y robs , carriage robs and z screw thread need to be in different length although).

title: Kreg Router table dust collection adaptor for 1.25in shop vac

description.text:
This is a Hose adaptor for a 1.25 inch shop vac to a Kreg router table dust collection port.
If you're thinking about potentially using it for something else the important dimensions are as follows...
outer diameter large hole 2.3 in
inner diameter large hole 2.1 in
outer diameter small hole 1.39 in
inner diameter small hole 1.24 in
Normal distance from top hole to bottom hole 3.13 in
Max diameter 2.69 in

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Orientate so small hose fitting is on the bottom to avoid using supports.

Raft is just there to help ensure the starting layer sticks through the entire print. I reduced the raft margin to 2mm as I didn't think more would be necessary.

The fixed shell starting point setting disabled to avoid having one of those unsightly zippers down the part.

1Hr 45Min print time on my printer. No cleanup was required.

print_settings.Notes:: This proved very testing to print. It may be my new extruder, but at 0.15mm layers I had a lot of prints where the head clogged at 0.9mm height. I sorted this, and then had two prints where the print bed dislodged (and jammed the print head) at exactly the same 16.6mm print height. Making sure my filament feed was near perfect and improving the bed location and fixing seem to have solved the issues, but be warned!

description.text:
This is a re-railer for G scale model railways such as LGB, Bachmann etc.
I found that some cheap Chinese Nuquida coach copies were derailing on some of my inverse curves, so made this to try and get them back on track.
It uses four screws to hold and align the track. The screws I used were 3.5mm by 16, and these extend just below the re-railer bottom surface.

I have attached the 123D file so you can modify the design if your railway does not use LGB locos.

Printer:

Shapeoko

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2 layers, 0.4 nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This proved very testing to print. It may be my new extruder, but at 0.15mm layers I had a lot of prints where the head clogged at 0.9mm height. I sorted this, and then had two prints where the print bed dislodged (and jammed the print head) at exactly the same 16.6mm print height. Making sure my filament feed was near perfect and improving the bed location and fixing seem to have solved the issues, but be warned!

background

This is actually the ninth iteration of my design. Some points learnt during the design are:
It would be helpful to have a guide on the outside of the wheels, but the LGB pickups on the engines extend over the rail head by about 2mm. and above the rail by about the same. Some LGB engines, notably the Stanz, have parts of their running gear that then extend down to only 3mm or so above the track, so even though a cantilevered guide is just possible, (but difficult to print) it does scrape on the engine as it passes.
The standard back to back distance for G scale wheels is about 40mm, with 6mm wheels (including the flanges). The inner dimension of the re-railer must accommodate this, but the LGB track cleaner I have has a back to back of about 38mm. This may be a fault introduced when the cleaning wheels were replaced, but the re-railer has been designed to allow these cleaning wheels through without binding.
The centre diamond is about 2mm above the rails. This helps align the wheels as they re-rail, higher would be better, but it would then foul on other "low parts" of the LGB locomootives.

I have attached the 123D file so you can modify the design if your railway does not use LGB locos.

title: Mk10 Filament Release Lever Catch (Cocoon Create, Wanhao Di3v2, etc.)

description.text:
A Lever catch that makes it easy to change filament on the Mk10 extruder one-handed.

My left hand and arm are almost fully paralyzed from a brain injury which makes changing filament a real PITA (go ahead, try doing it yourself one-handed). So I created a catch that holds the release lever down while I change the filament at my leisure. It mounts onto the stock extruder carriage bracket above the nozzle fan (I've modded mine to a rear mounted fan but it should still work in stock configuration.

comments.text: Awesome
comments.author: Renfeld

comments.text: Looking forward to trying this. A stroke left me one armed and I havent found a more practical way to handle that lever one handed, hadn't considered locking it down though, i was looking at ways to build it up higher so I could hold it down with the side of my thumb leaving my fingers free to handle the filament. Thanks!
comments.author: pelmen

comments.text: Sorry to hear about your stroke and its effects.  I hope you are able to get the clip installed and working, it really makes the process much more bearable. Let me know if you have any problems with fit and I'll see if i can tweak it for you.
comments.author: pelmen

comments.text:
I eventually got it installed, took me time to find new bolts as the existing ones are too short to accomodate this piece. As printed your model didnt work so well for me, the lever didnt come down quite far enough to catch your hook and when i forced it it wouldnt hold the lever either. I modified and reprinted the model, now it works great. I raised the hook by 0.5mm and extended its latching area out by 0.5mm.
There is a little play with the fan and the mounting holes when doing up the bolts, so maybe it wasnt perfectly aligned on my first attempt. Anyway, its all good now and working fine. Great design thanks!
comments.author: PlasticCow

comments.text: I have the same problem sometimes with it slipping off. Can you share the updated model?
comments.author: pelmen

This original hook was a perfect fit, but would sometimes sag for heavier objects. I modified it to have a curve so that the hooks will stay in place. I'm not really sure why, but most of the hooks I've looked for don't have this. I uploaded two different types for different uses.

comments.text: Well done. I've got a lot of these around the house now. I'm trying to point more traffic toward your design with my hook's cover photo. The remix that ReeseAllen did of yours looks cool too.

comments.text: i was just thinking how i couldn't find a decent peg hook that has the curved top... after many downloads and deletes. I was on the verge of opening SCAD and starting my own (functioning) set of peg things but you stopped me. thanks? regardless i appreciate your peg hook thing so thanks
comments.author: cbolton911

comments.text: I was just thinking this hook would be way better if the top was curved, good job.

remixed_from.author: Brandano
remixed_from.title: 3DRAG/K8200 Z axis cable driven parallel drive system

title: K8200 Z axis rework - cable driven

description.text:
This is an evolution of my Z axis parallel drive, taking advantage of the cable to isolate the oscillations caused by a bent or misaligned threaded rod that normally show up as horizontal ridges in the print.
The Z axis motor is moved to the top of the frame, with the threaded rod placed horizontally and pulling on the cable sideways. To make space for it the top element of the frame is repositioned flush with the top of the columns, which means that two of the metal corner brackets have to be removed. I have added printed brackets that fit on both sides of the frames and also double as supports for the small pulleys, that should restore the lost rigidity.
The cable I used is a steel clothesline covered by a 4mm plastic sheath, and the parts are dimensioned to get a good grip on it, but will need to be reworked for a different diameter. The cable also conflicts with the stock bolts that fix the LM10UU bearings to aluminium plate on the left of the carriage, I have replaced mine with flatter ones that barely clear the cable, but it would probably be better to use countersunk bolts.
I have re-designed the pulleys as well to have a reasonable overhang, but am currently using the ones from my earlier mod, so can't guarantee the new ones will work fine. They will probably require some adjustment.
The SCAD file makes use of some features that are only present in the latest development snapshots, specifically the rotation angle in the rotate_extrude() function, so thingiverse will not render it properly in its previews.
The part that holds the nut is built to house two of them, to handle the twisting load caused by the weight of the z axis. Currently it causes a fair deal of friction, and I had to increase the driver current to the z axis motor. I will probably rework it for a deeper and looser fit over the nut. Nylon M8 nuts would probably work better, I am still experimenting with this.

06-05-2016: Moved the smooth rod to the front of the frame, closer to the cable, to further reduce deflections caused by a bent threaded rod and to reduce friction. Reworked the carriage to use an LM8UU linear bearing. Currently I am using a printed PLA one. The plan is to eliminate the two aluminium plates on the left of the Z axis and move one of the m10 smooth rods on the right of the printer. This would free up the m8 smooth rod and linear bearing for the top of the printer, but will probably require a separate m8 smooth rod support to make use of the entire range of movement and recover the space used up by the threaded rod coupler.

30-04-2016: Added a Z endstop switch bracket. Added small tools to insert and optionally extract 608 bearings in the pulleys, using a piece of threaded rod and a few washers. Modified the corner brackets to have slots in place of the double mounting holes, to allow some adjustments in placing the upper pulleys and allowing the use of larger diameter ones if wanted. Reduced the large pulley lightening hole diameter to make it simpler to slice. Added an unused stronger upper pulley, 3mm larger. To use these the carriage tie point has to be shifted upward by 3 mm.

27-04-2016: I have reworked the carriage to be easier to fit so it runs freely. I have also updated the SCAD file so that the modules follow more closely the names of the exported STL files.

comments.text:
Amazing work ! It really looks like you made a big inprovement on your first design.
I might look into using this design and maby take a look on how i would improve on it.
I still think the pulleys would need a better design. (if they were to be printed vs bought).
But i think this might be the best idea on how to do it so far. Nice thinking ! I also thought
about it at one point because of the tentioners i have on top, if you remember my build.
comments.author: Joey_3D

comments.text: I have completely remodelled the entire thing in OpenSCAD, and re-designed the pulleys so that the overhang never exceeds 45 degrees. the smaller ones could probably be made a bit bigger, but then the holes in the corner brackets will have to be moved accordingly. It might be a good idea to make the holes the pulleys mount to into slots to allow some adjustment. Tright now my biggest issue is that the weight of the Z axis causes a lot of friction by twisting the carriage arm, putting a side load on the nuts. I Am thinking of moving the antirotation smooth rod close to the point where the carriage is tied to the cable and putting bushings or linear bearings on it to take care of the twisting load.
comments.author: Joey_3D

comments.text:
Maby you could move the anker points to the center of the carrage so you don't have a twisting force on it.
Or put a second cable on the other side that also pulls it up to counter it.
comments.author: Brandano

comments.text:
Yes, that would be ideal, but the trouble is that the leadscrew should go through the center of the carriage as well. the only way this would be physically possible would be by having the cable running on both sides of the leadscrew, which would mean more pulleys, a longer cable and added complexity, or having two leadscrews running on opposite sides of the cable, which would mean some gearing arrangement, and again more complexity. In the meantime I have re-arranged things so that the cable is tied close to the antirotation linear bearing, which makes the whole carriage more compact, and made the space between the two drive nuts deeper. This is the version I am using now, the parts are already published: http://imgur.com/E3WQUYM
I didn't want to re-print the motor holder, so I re-used one of the smooth rod holders and only printed a new one for the other end of the rod.
comments.author: Joey_3D

description.text:
These are replacement parts for the door stoppers of the Morpheus Mark IV printer, aimed to keep the resin vat down when the buildplate lifts.
Remove the door stoppers (left and right lower corners), then add the smaller part to the existing holes with the same screws, plug the bigger part into the smaller part and drop in a nail to allow the bigger part to swivel.

description.text:
A "D" cell to add a power supply to those devices that run on them but have no external power connections. This has an Ebay LM2596 adjustable regulator that is set to the required voltage. Print other cells as needed to fill the battery compartment, and just have a connection from one end to the other.

I printed the first one and found it was the wrong way around so it has been mirrored to fix it. You can see this in the "straight through" cell pictured.
It could be the cells are a little long as they are fairly firm in the holder of the toy sewing machine I've tested it in but it is working ok.

Later, I may shorten it by a mm or so.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dwT8uG6CFeq

description.text:

Added a "light version" which is basically just a holder for the antenna tubes. My favorite so far.

I have also added an updated file for the "full" version. Check out the file with "UPDATE" in the name. This should be more durable - especially the holders for the antenna tubes.

Should fit on the better Lisam clones.
This version has a smaller antenna angle (46 instead of 60 degree) for more clearence to the props.
This should allow the tray to sit flush on the bottom plate of the frame.

So; Go for it ;)

title: PlayBox - Raspberry Pi entertainment system (music/radio/video/retro gaming)

description.text:
I built this as a replacement for my broken Squeezebox. It is primarily for streaming music and radio (hence the audiophile DAC) but also does the usual RPi stuff like running game console emulators (with a compatible blue tooth controller) and Plex.

The OLED display is really bright and can easily be read from across the room (see https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ot0-deq33PA). It is driven by my own software - I'll attach the code once it reaches maturity or you can contact me if you'd like a development snapshot.

If you'd like to build your own you'll need the following:

  • Raspberry Pi 2/3
  • OLED display - https://www.adafruit.com/products/2674
  • Pi DAC+ - http://www.iqaudio.co.uk/home/8-pi-dac-0712411999650.html
  • A handful of female to female jumper cables
  • Six M2.5 x 8mm hex bolts and nuts

title: Wanhao i3 Standalone Z-stop extender (Fully 3D printed)

description.text:
[ No nuts, bolts, or any other accessory needed except your 3D printer. Just download, print, attach, re-level, and you're done! :D ]

Upon installing a glass bed (from Wanhao), I found out that the bed surface is now higher than the hot end tip... and I can't adjust it anymore using the bed screws or by re-positioning the Z-endstop. I also don't have M2s and M3 screws, so it would be hard to make the available endstops in Thingiverse. So I thought of a simple solution: if you can't raise the endstop, 'lower' the carriage!

This very simple standalone Z-stop 'extender' in designed to allow the endstop to click at a higher Z, giving you the clearance you need for installing glass plates. Print then install this by pushing it upward through one side of the x-motor carriage (the one along the y-axis: see orange arrows on the photos)(longer side facing the edge of the printer). Make sure that you position it in that when the X-axis lowers, this thing would hit the Z-stop instead of the X-motor carriage. If it doesn't fit, scale it up slightly along the X axis (or Y, depending on your slicer) to widen the gap, OR leave a comment so I can manually resize the gap. To increase/decrease the Z-clearance, scale it up/down by 5%. This extender will give you 3-6mm additional clearance. Re-level your hot bed after installation.

title: The Gameπ - Handheld Retro Gaming Console

description.text:
When I first stumbled upon the various Handheld Raspberry Pi Retro Gaming Consoles, I knew I needed to build one. I didn't want to simply copy someone else's design though, I wanted the challenge of designing and building my own custom game console. There are great examples out there and I wanted to combine all of their strengths into one design. The initial cost of these can be $200+, so I also wanted to make it affordable while not skimping on the functionality.The main goal was to minimize hardware and cost and maximize the features. I was able to build this RetroPie handheld gaming console for $100. Check out my site at http://cookingcircuits.com/home/thegamepi or http://www.instructables.com/id/The-Game%CF%80-Handheld-Retro-Gaming-Console-Complete-G/ for a detailed guide!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jiEPAt7BP60

title: Indexed Bolt Hobbing Jig for rotary tool

description.text:
I never had any luck hobbing a bolt using the tap method. When I used my rotary tool by hand, the teeth came out uneven. This work in progress jig should allow for either a 8mm, or 5/16" bolt (or rod with nut) to be indexed to 19 positions. The ratchet head was edited from this excellent thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8752 I put up a short 30 second video of this jig being used. I was holding the camera, and using the rotary tool and making sparks fly all at the same time. With some practice, I feel I will be able to make many bolts for my army of 3D printers. http://youtu.be/KpnZK_AJLgM
  • Edit -
    • The idea for this thing came to me after seeing many great ways/things to hob bolts. (That and after the snow I didn't want to go out to the cold work shed) My thing is an amalgamation of many of the ideas found here on Thingiverse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9291
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10360
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10110
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11275

Print one Ratchet gear
Print one Block -Place a bolt into the ratchet gear so that the bolt head sits flush with the gear.
-Insert the bolt into the jig block.
-if you have one, insert a 608 bearing into the jig, and snug it in with a nut and washer
-secure the jig in a vice, or clamp. (or hold it if you feel brave)
-use a rotary tool to grind your first tooth into the bolt
-rotate the bolt clockwise one notch
-use a rotary tool to grind tooth into the bolt
-rotate and repeat This was designed with Sketchup. The skp file has been added for others to work with.

title: Alien Pencil Case - Take Me To Your Leader -  #backtoschool

description.text: Designed for the backtoschool challange, this is a pencil case that assembles into an alien. The alien can be in a seated or standing position. The eyes, feet, and hands are all pencil toppers which go into the main body and head. The alien also brought his sign which is a metric and standard ruler and fits between the rockets for storage. The alien comes equipped with rocket pack which the pencils are stored in when you're on the go. The toppers when removed all fit in the main body. The head is held tight to the body by the pencils in the rocket pack. Video Explanation Available at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iE_aNFVjMnc

-The head requires supports to allow the lip which fits into the body.  
-The holes are designed for small diameter pencils and may require some filing or sanding to fit larger pencils (figured too small is better than too big).

description.text: An experiment with using text on the outside and a magnet closed inside the object.

This is one part. I printed it on the Ultimaker and it is 5 x 5 x 0.7 cm. It took 1:19 hour to print. The lid is to cover a box which is still in the make. The Lid has a hole in the frontside in which a magnet is placed (10x4x3mm). The hole is a little bigger (10.4x4.1x3.3mm). I placed the magnet during the proces.
The second part is the container. It took 2:54 hours to make and it is 5 x 5 x 5 cm. This container has no magnet inside. That container is still to come.
The third part is also a container.(Container with Magnet). It took around 3 hours to make and it is 5 x 5 x 5 cm height.
All the magnets I used are 10 x 3 x 4 mm.
The fourth part is another lid without decoration. It has a magnet inside. Together with the box it will make an exact 5 x 5 x 5 cm cube. It took 1:15 hour to print.
When you put the magnets inside the object be aware of the poles...

Many-use disk coffee filter for AeroPress, made from PP (polypropilene) with CNC router
It may be necessary to use thin sandbox to polish the thing after it is finished

I have metallic disk coffee filter for AeroPress which I've bought for about $9 several years ago. But days ago I've built my first CNC milling router, and just thing that it is precise enough to drill several thousand small holes and make a new, free and shiny filter for me.

Material

I've used a head of meal container, which is made from 0.5mm plain PP plastic.
It is enough to have a circle with dia 82 mm.

Instruments

I've used 0.3mm drill bit (better to use 0.4mm),
and standard end mill bit (dia 3.125mm)

Milling process

FIrst, use drill bit and drill the filter. Since PP is very soft material, it is ok to drill with feedrate = 150 mm/min. You can use MeshCAM 'drill holes' tool to make G-Code for it.
All the holes (>1500 pieces) will be milled in about 40 minutes.

Then run the second op - engraving the edge down to 0.3mm (since AeroPress doesn't like thick filters), and cutting out the whole filter.
Use enough speed of milling (400mm/min is quite good) and enough steps (0.5 or even 1mm is ok also). Warning, that if you set too low values here (i.e. low speed, small step), the spinning mill will became hot because of contact with plastic, and it will not cut, but meld it, which definitely ruine your job.

Finally it is desirable to scrab the surface of ready filter in order to remove all drilling artefacts from it.

Have a nice coffee break!

description.text:
An INSULATED 12oz beverage container. Looks rather NAUTICAL as it appears to be a pile of COILED ROPE. PERFECTLY SIZED for standard 12oz can. Keeps that favorite beverage cool and you can say that YOU made it! It is anti-spill by being a bit wider at the base than the top. Insulation is achieved by printing at 10% INFILL. Insulating airpockets are formed. You can watch them being printed. ALSO, it is watertight AND FLOATS.

I printed in ABS at 230 degrees C with 10% infill and WITH RAFT. NOSUPPORT. Resolution is up to you. I printed at .27 and it is great. Other materials may produce different or better results. I prefer ABS. The finished product is practically indestructible.

Quite the long print (5-6 hours) so be ready. The result is truly worth it. Color choice is yours.

title: Kossel Pro Fan Part Fan Upgrade

description.text:
UPDATE: I have uploaded a base for a 35x35x10mm fan (fan_adapter_base_35.stl) and renamed the base for a 30x30x10 fan to fan_adapter_base_30.stl.

This is a fan upgrade for the Kossel Pro delta printer or the Kossel RepRap variant that uses the same stock effector.

The stock effector uses (3) diminutive 10mm 5V fans; (1) for the hot end and (2) for part cooling. Sadly, while the fans are adequate for most smaller prints, larger prints with small areas will need to have the fan settings adjusted to get it to print well. In fact, you have to run them wide open most of the time.

However, there is a solution: use bigger fans!

This thing is an adapter to mount (2) 30x30x10mm 5V radial fans to replace the two smaller axial fans. With this upgrade, you no longer have to run the fans wide open to get decent prints for parts with smaller details.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.30

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print with ABS. PLA will become soft on longer prints.

Clean all parts and test fit them before assembly.

Installation - moderately difficult

Parts Needed:

  • (2) 30x30x10mm 5V fans: yes, 5 volts.
  • (2) 1.5x15mm bolts
  • (2) 1.5mm nuts
  • zip ties (optional)
  • googly eyes (optional)

Notes: The best way to install these is to remove the effector and the hot end. You will need to get inside the effector to get to the small nuts that hold the fans. You could invert the arms but I don't recommend that as you are sure to drop one of the nuts into the effector. Having it out of the machine will allow you to rotate it to allow the nut to drop out. Be sure to test fit the fans to ensure they fit into the base snugly and that you can insert the bolt to hold them in place. Use a small parts tray to keep track of the smaller bits.

  1. Unload the filament. Allow the hot end to cool. Power off the printer.
  2. Remove the hot end. Place it aside and wrap a cloth around it to protect it.
  3. Disconnect the wire loom to the effort. Move the wire loom to the side and out of the way.
  4. Disconnect the delta arms at the effector. You do not need to remove the arms themselves. Be sure to capture the bolts, grommets, and any bearings that drop out. Set these aside.
  5. Place the effector on a static free cloth or on a workbench with a lip (to keep those pesky small parts from rolling away).
  6. Remove the two 5V axial fans and disconnect the wires. Remember which one is the red (positive) wire! Just loosen the bolts for the wires - don't remove them completely.
  7. Install the fan adapter risers in place of the fans. For this you will need needle nose pliers to hold the nuts in place. It's a bit tricky but you can do it with some patience.
  8. Install the new fans in the base. Use the 1.5mm bolt and nut to secure them.
  9. Coat the top of the riser and the inside of the base where the riser fits with a generous amount of acetone using a small brush or similar applicator (but not enough for it to run all over - be careful there!). Wait about 5-10 seconds then press the parts together, orient them as shown in the photos, and hold them for about 30 seconds until the acetone evaporates.
  10. Thread the wires for the fans through the same holes from the old fans, cut the wires to length and connect them.
  11. Install the effector. Be careful not to over tighten the arm bolts. Note: this would be a good time to install shims to correct the bolt length issue if you've been wanting to do that.
  12. Reinstall the hot end.
  13. Reconnect the wire loom and PTFE tube.
  14. Zip tie the loose ends and apply googly eyes (optional).
  15. Power on the printer and load the filament.
  16. (optional but highly recommended) Calibrate your printer.
  17. Change the settings in your software to lower print fan speeds on first layers (they're way more efficient now and may cause problems if turned on 100% on first layers).

Designed with Openscad

If you find other sized fans (you can use up to 35x35x15mm fans but not much larger - no room), let me know and I'll make and upload a version for you.

title: ALDI/Jaycar 33 Drawer Parts Cabinet Drawer Divider

description.text: If you've ever purchased the ALDI/Jaycar 33 drawer parts cabinets you will have no doubt realized that there are only enough drawer divider included to do half the drawers. I've copied the originals, but made them a touch thicker and a much better fit than the originals. I print them vertically in batches of about 20 with the thick edge down and no supports or rafts. Just be sure to select 'infill print after perimeter' to get a nicer looking part, you can experiment with fill densities, I've settled on about 50%
